content.description: Utilize small, well-placed pockets requiring sufficient balance and mental prowess to top out this baby - good movement with good feet yields a good time. Stay off the arete to receive maximum points.
content.protection: A pad or two, as a small boulder sits under the overhang at the base.
content.location: This is the leftmost problem on the southern slab.

content.description: Containing less pockets than its neighbors, this problem involves more careful movement.
content.protection: One pad is sufficient; this problem has the best landing of the three on the slab.
content.location: This is the middle route on the southern slab - stick to the blankest section to keep it interesting.

content.description: Climb the right side of the West face left of the arete, beginning in the tan rock and finishing up higher on the darker stone.
content.protection: This has a slightly weird landing.
content.location: It is just north of the arete on the SW corner.

content.description: Climb up on classic, sharp, limestone pockets. Woohoo.
content.protection: A single pad and a helmet for style.
content.location: Start on the bottom-left on the west-facing face, and traverse to the center section. Then go straight up, sticking primarily to the black colored rock.

content.description:
This boulder problem follows the rounded arete left of

PPE

. Start low on a good left hand edge and shallow right hand pocket. Some edges and pinchy pockets lead to an off balance crux move.

Top out on some easier holds.

This problem is named after the large groups of basketball short wearing, toprope clustering, switchback cutting, loud music playing, gym belay tag wearing people above this nice boulder.

This problem has been done many times before me. I gave it a random name, but if you have more details, I'll change it.
content.protection: A pad? It has a soft, sandy landing below.
content.location:
Follow the rounded arete left of

PPE

.

content.description: Traverse left-to-right from pockets to ledges, moving upward towards the upper right corner. All your handholds are on the black rock.
content.protection: A few pads might be good to protect the entire traverse.
content.location:
Start low and left in pockets, traverse up and right using obvious angled ledges, and top out on the upper right corner. In other words, climb

PPE

. but continue right instead of going up at the center.

content.description:
This has more pockets than

Undercover Hashbrown

, but it has a sketchier landing. Stay off the arete, but only if you want to.
content.protection: A pad or two; a small tree makes strategic placement difficult.
content.location: It is the right line up the southern slab.

content.description: This is arete slapping and heel hooking at its best. The initial move up to a not-so-great spot on the arete seems like the crux. From there, enjoy the heels. Climb it twice if you want. Enjoy the outdoors. Smile.
content.protection: A pad is all that's necessary.
content.location: Begin with a low sit-start on the bottom left overhung corner of the west face, and climb straight up using the slab's arete.

content.description: Start matched on the great crimp rail that's tinged light brown. Move out left to a good sidepull then up & right to a pocketed pinch. Throw your left hand above to the sharp two finger pocket, move your feet, and go up to the right hand crimp (crux). Move your left hand to the next pocket, and top out with minor pockets and precarious feet.
content.location:
Start right of the northwest arete (in between

Piggy Bank Gumbies

and

PPE

).
